Class FlightScheduler

  • java.lang.Object
    • FlightScheduler

  • public class FlightScheduler
extends java.lang.Object
    Assignment 2 - COMP2911. This program implements a state space search. The initial state is in Sydney with a given number of required flights. The goal state can occur in any node, but all the required flights must have been traversed. The path cost is the delay at each node (excluding the first and last nodes). At each node, you are able to move to any other node. The running time of this program can be improved in two main ways. 1: Heuristic. Changing the way the heuristic is calculated reduces the number of states you need to search by appropriately sorting the states in the PriorityQueue. As a result, you will be able to expand the least-cost path earlier, reducing the total number of states you need to expand and hence increasing the speed of your program. However, you need to take care in ensuring that the heuristic remains admissible so that the search will find the lowest cost path in all cases. 2: Expansion. Carefully choosing which states to expand can reduce the number of expansions hence making the program faster.
    Author:
    Claudia Tu z3459448

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Takes in a text file that lists the airports, the delays incurred at each airport, the travel time between each pair of airports and the required flights. Then it performs an A* search to determine the lowest cost sequence of flights between the airports that covers all the required flights. This cost and the number of nodes expanded is printed out, as well as the sequence of flights.
        Parameters:
        args - [0] Location of text file.

      • search

        public void search(java.util.HashSet<Edge> requiredEdges,
          Expansion str,
          Graph g,
          Heuristic h)
        This function implements an A* search using a PriorityQueue. The search is a state space search. In the initial state, our plane starts in Sydney airport. In the goal state, there are no required flights left to take. These required flights are passed in as a HashSet of edges. Airports are represented as nodes and flights are represented as edges in the Graph. The search also takes in a strategy used to expand States and a heuristic used to estimate the cost left until the goal state. In addition, this search stores a set of visited states and checks that a state has not already been visited before checking its neighbours. We do not need to check if a newer state has a lower cost because the heuristic used is consistent, that is, it only increases as the search reaches the goal state.
        Parameters:
        requiredEdges - The edges that need to be traversed.
        str - The strategy to use to expand States.
        g - The graph representation of the airports.
        h - The heuristic to use to estimate the cost remaining until the goal state.
